page.description: The FOR EACH ... NEXT operators allow you to step through a list, collection, or array without knowing the number of elements that it contains.
page.syntax: FOR EACH Placeholder IN List [ statements ] [ CONTINUE ] [ statements ] [ EXIT FOR ] NEXT

argument.name: Placeholder
argument.description: An arbitrary name. When referring to the placeholder value inside the loop, reference the variable's *[xb:.value]* property. See examples below.

argument.name: List
argument.description: The name of a CR-LF delimited list, an array, or a collection.

discussion.p: The *[xb:FOR EACH ... NEXT]* operator loops through a list, collection, or array, allowing you iterate over each element. As you iterate through the list, collection, or array the element for the current position in the list is stored in a *[xb:Placeholder]*. The *[xb:Placeholder]* contains information about the element, including its value. In order to reference the value for the current position in the list, you must use the *[xb:value]* property for the place holder. For example, *[xb:Foo.value]*.
The example below demonstrates iterating over a CR-LF delimited list containing the letters 'a' through 'e' and displays a message box for each letter, skipping the letter 'c'.

page.note: This example will only run in Desktop applications or the Interactive Window in Alpha Anywhere as the [ui_msg_box function] only works in Desktop applications.
page.example:
dim letters as C = <<%txt% a b c d e %txt%
FOR EACH letter IN letters 'refer to the placeholder .value property to get the value of the current element in letters. if (letter.value = "c") then CONTINUE end if
ui_msg_box("", letter.value) NEXT
